This is a different take on the drab charger for the rechargeable batteries.PROS -1. Better LED Display allowing for much better understanding of Charge level as well as battery conditioning.2. Acts as a Powerbank in a pinch.3. Smart Selection of Charging mode. Think of Rapid charging for batteries.4. Avoids OverchargingCONS -1. Only two batteries can be charged at a time.2. There's no wall Plug included.Essentially this is a charger for two  AA AAA AAAA or C batteries. Unlike traditional chargers which feature a built in wall plug this item has a wire with a USB to MicroUSB conversion. Under normal usage it will be plugged into wall via a USB charger plug (Not Included). In a pinch you could plug the USB end of the wire into the full USB port on the device and plug the microusb end into your phone. In such a case you will be required to put in two C Rechargeable batteries included.Similar to Qi Rapid chargers for android phones (Lightning chargers for iPhone) this device determines charging current based on charge left on the batteries. This is rather innovative and reduces the charge times. There's also a Conditioning Mode which can resuscitate dying rechargeable batteries. Mind you I have not tested that part as yet.

This multi-type battery recharger charges two rechargeable batteries (Li-Ion NiCad etc.) of AA or AAA size or 18650 size using spring-loaded battery holders.  The charger has circuitry to detect the battery type to avoid overcharging which is very important to prevent battery case rupture or combustion.  In addition the charge has battery charge completion indicators (using blue LEDs) for each battery to enable the user to visually see the status of the charging process.  This charger is designed to be powered from a 5 vdc USB port on a PC or Mac.  Another interesting feature is that the charger with charged batteries can be used as a battery extender; i.e. it can charge other devices plugged into it after being removed from the USB power source.  The build quality is sufficient for its intended home-use design and for that reason I give it four stars.  A fifth star would be possible with a more robust design.  The charger unit cannot be plugged into a 110 VAC wall outlet; just the 5vdc USB power source.I purchased the charger with two 18650 style batteries that I use for my work flashlight.  So far the batteries seem to be acceptable but I've only charged them once so far and their lifespan in terms of number of charge cycles has yet to be verified.  The batteries are rated at 3200mAH each which is typical for this style.  Beware of any current technology 18650 battery on the market that claims higher charge capacity than 3200 mAH.  Fortunately the two batteries that came with the Victagen charger seem to be labeled honestly.  For these reasons I recommend the Victagen charger with two 18650 3200 MAH batteries.  Check the price but the old adage you get what you pay for is true here too.

Planned a camping trip to the Southwest on short notice.  Knowing we were going to be staying in less developed campsites a table would be a key convenience but it had to fly with the rest of the gear without exceeding checked-bag weight and bulk.  This seemed like just the thing and I was far from disappointed. Due to the low price I went ahead and bought both sizes and found them to be so light and compact that I packed both. Setup is super easy though fitting the top requires enough tension and finicky orientation of the flat tube that the kids needed help with just that step.  It takes just 30-45 seconds including removal from the bag: it's that quick.  The table is strong and reasonably firm due to the tension across the top and the rigid battens.  If we had one quibble it's that the cupholders are perfect for a can or standard bottle but if you add a coozy or want to stash a larger bottle ( cooking oil during food prep e.g.) the diameter is too small.  Breakdown is as quick as setup.  We used the larger table for dining with 4 small chairs we brought to set gear on while loading the car and for food prep.  The smaller one made a handy side table near the fire and fit nicely in the tent vestibule to keep shoes and gear off the ground.  We even found that if we left off the top it made a perfect elevated stand for our Coleman stove.  Try this at your own risk of course but it worked great for us though it required propping the propane canister so it didn't hang free at the side ( our usual liquid fuel model would work better) .  We were actually at an unbelievably gorgeous and isolated National Forest campsite overlooking a red rock canyon just a few miles from Bryce when I checked my email for the first time in days and was gratified to find a personal thank-you note from the storefront owner with extra setup tips.  The tips were unnecessary as we had just enjoyed a meal prepared on one table and served on the other and had moved on to enjoy beer and cookies by the fire with the smaller one.  The tables really were key gear for making the trip work and I look forward to discovering the many more ways they will surely prove themselves useful.

I am baffled by this camping cookware set. Not by the various options and features though. I like the ecologically sound inclusion of a section of loofah and the bamboo spatula.But whatever gains come from the latter the overuse of plastic bags is beyond belief. Each lid bowl piece was encased in its own ocean-killing plastic bag. Two more large pieces of plastic was also used to keep the smaller box from sliding around in the larger box (sticking with the babushka theme) in which this cookware set was needlessly packed. There is no reason whatsoever that the actual box would not be fine to ship this nonbreakable cookware set.Then there is this puzzling bit of information in the owner's manual: Not suitable for stoves ovens or microwaves. Only use on campfires? So does that mean a portable camp stove or even a table top camp stove may not be used in conjunction with this cookware?Hard to recommend this item at this time. I previously owned a pair of Sades SA930 and SA810 headphones and much of this review will be in a comparison to them. Neither pair lasted 6 months. Eventually the Mute switch died then the audio would get patchy or the mic went out. I went with a different brand hoping to get better quality.The SA930 are a bit smaller than the SA810 but otherwise identical.The GoodThe Headset is light and doesn't weigh the head down after using it for a few hours.The Mic head is connected on a flexible band so you can adjust it into the perfect spot.The Mic arm is on a swivel so you can move it out of the way.The cable is super long over 6 feet.The cable has a hook and loop wrap on it so you can keep the unused portion neatly bunched up.The cable has a nice woven cover that feels like quality.There is a volume adjustment and mute button on the cord.The USB connector is for lights only and is connected pretty close to the plug so it doesn't get in the way when not in use.The Bad:It's just not comfortable.Had I worn these before the SA810 they would have rated 3 maybe 4 stars in comfort but really they pale in comparison. So much so that I am going to return them and get another pair of SA810 this time with a Warranty.The top cushion is nice but it is too firm for how light the headset is and so it just acts as a big buffer and is less comfortable than a wider flatter style.The material of the ear cushions don't breathe so my head gets sweaty after wearing them for a while.The ear cushions are too big or the ear cavities are too small either way they are not 'over the ear' so my ears get cramped. I don't feel it while wearing them but after a couple of hours I take them off and my ears just hurt and ache.The plug jacket it too wide so I can't plug them into my phone with it's current case. If I were going to keep them I would have to shave some plastic off.People I have talked to said I am not as clear. Not bad but not as clear as I used to be when speaking.
